author: matthias
post: Yes, it’s hard to distill it as one reason, but the biggest one for me is that the image is inherently unlike what we would expect from a 13th/14th century artist, most particularly the ultra realism of the image (the kinked leg and turned in foot on the dorsal image is a big one for me), the nudity, and a number of the blood marks. Great question and very articulate for a 14 year old!.

post: Hugh This review provides a logical rebuttal of De Wesselow’s claim that the sheet/s at the Pharos and the Sheet that de Clari referred to as being raised every week were one and the same thing, but what it does not do is refute the claim that the sheet that de Clari refers to is the Shroud, and that this is one and the same as the Mandylion. If the Mandylion was at the Pharos in 1201, that doesn’t mean that it couldn’t have been the sheet that de Clari refers to at the other church in 1204, does it?.
